article_title: Book Review: 'The Light and the Dark' by Mikhail Shiskin
article_text: Late in 'Anna Karenina,' in some of the book's most luminous chapters, Tolstoy dramatizes the birth of Kitty and Levin's first child. The delivery is protracted and difficult; Kitty's suffering is acute. For Levin, too, the tension, the helplessness and anticipation are so intense that they seem to form a rift in his very understanding of life. He feels he has "lost sense of time." Despite years of atheism, he has begun involuntarily appealing to God and realizes that only once before, beside his brother's deathbed, had he experienced something comparable: "That had been grief and this was joy. But...

twitter.description: With an epistolary novel, Mikhail Shishkin demonstrates that he is heir to Tolstoy, Pasternak and Grossman. Sam Sacks reviews "The Light and the Dark."

article_metadata.author: Sam Sacks
article_metadata.article.origheadline: Book Review: ‘The Light and the Dark’ by Mikhail Shiskin

article_summary:
He feels he has "lost sense of time."
Late in 'Anna Karenina,' in some of the book's most luminous chapters, Tolstoy dramatizes the birth of Kitty and Levin's first child.
For Levin, too, the tension, the helplessness and anticipation are so intense that they seem to form a rift in his very understanding of life.
The delivery is protracted and difficult; Kitty's suffering is acute.
Despite years of atheism, he has begun involuntarily appealing to God and realizes that only once before, beside his brother's deathbed, had he experienced something comparable: "That had been grief and this was joy.
